McGill University
Paula Harder
paula.harder@mila.quebec

Abstract
The availability of reliable, high-resolution climate and weather data is crucial for making informed decisions on climate adaptation and mitigation, as well as for guiding rapid responses to extreme events. Forecasting models are limited by computational costs, often resulting in coarse-resolution predictions. Statistical downscaling can provide an efficient method for upsampling low-resolution data. In this field, deep learning has been successfully applied, often using image super-resolution methods from computer vision. However, these models often violate physical laws when predicting physical variables. To address this issue, we develop methods that guarantee physical constraints are satisfied by a deep downscaling model while also increasing its performance according to traditional metrics.

We introduce two ways of constraining the network: a normalization layer added to the end of the neural network and a successive approach that scales with increasing upsampling factors. We demonstrate the applicability of our methods across different popular architectures and upsampling factors using ERA5 reanalysis data.

Introduction
Accurate modeling of weather and climate is critical for taking effective action to combat climate change. Local and regional predictions shape adaptation decisions and provide impetus for action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Predicted and observed quantities such as precipitation, wind speed, and temperature impact decisions in fields like agriculture, energy, and transportation. While these quantities are often required at a fine geographical and temporal scale, most climate and weather models are extremely computationally expensive to run, resulting in coarse-resolution predictions, while observations are often sparsely available.

There is a need for fast methods that can generate high-resolution data based on the low-resolution models that are commonly available. The terms downscaling in climate science and super-resolution (SR) in machine learning refer to learning a mapping between a low-resolution (LR) input sample and a high-resolution (HR) version of that sample. Downscaling via established statistical methods has been long used by the climate science community to increase the resolution of climate data.

In parallel, computer vision SR has evolved rapidly using various deep learning architectures, including super-resolution convolutional neural networks (CNNs), generative adversarial models (GANs), vision transformers, and normalizing flows. Increasing the temporal resolution via frame interpolation is also an active area of research for video enhancement that can be transferred to spatio-temporal climate data.

Recently, deep learning approaches have been applied to a variety of climate and weather datasets, covering both model output data and observations. Climate super-resolution has mostly focused on CNNs, recently shifting towards GANs. Generating high-resolution data with machine learning can produce realistic-looking images and good predictive accuracy. However, a major obstacle often encountered when applying ML to a physical system such as the Earth's atmosphere is that the predicted output values can violate physical laws such as conservation of energy, momentum, and moisture.

We introduce a novel method to strictly enforce physical constraints between low-resolution (input) and high-resolution (output) images. Using ERA5 reanalysis data, we build datasets to learn the upsampling with different factors ranging from 2 to 16 times enhancement. We introduce a renormalization layer that can be added as the last layer to any network architecture or successively after each upsampling part, developing a new SR network architecture. Our methodology works across spatial SR, temporal SR, or frame interpolation.

Our novel constraining methodology is not only applicable to SR tasks in scientific areas but can also constrain neural networks for emulation and prediction. Climate model emulation tasks could benefit from using our constraining layer. Within the SR domain, our work could have implications beyond scientific datasets as the constraining methodologies can advance state-of-the-art SR more generally.
